author: jochembrouwer
content:
I suggest to not use the ABI decoder because this makes things more complex, since likely clients will use a ABI decoder (if we specify EIP to use an ABI decoder) and thus that decoder itself needs to be correct. I'll open a PR to EIPS/6110 to specify `parse_deposit_event_data` (currently not defined) a la Geth https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/d219e9b005358f96d85f4eb66e1418c605b2bb0f/core/types/deposit.go#L41 i.e. hardcode offset/length of the data

This is also in line with the Sepolia test released on <#892088344438255616>  by the testing team https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/892088344438255616/1346819508253360180

```python
def parse_deposit_data(deposit_event_data) -> bytes[]:
  """
  Parses deposit data from DepositContract.DepositEvent data
  """
  pass

def event_data_to_deposit_request(deposit_event_data) -> bytes:
    deposit_data = parse_deposit_data(deposit_event_data)
...
```

Draft is here: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9460

author: ben_a_adams
content:
Using an ABI isn't particularly important; what is important is the data fields are length prefixed byte arrays. The fixed offsets are a quirk of the current contracts.

Properly parsing (using length prefix) means it would still work if a contract on a different chain output the same data but trimmed leading zeros; however using fixed offsets would break (if the argument is not to use ABI because "it might change"; changing would first break the offsets)

author: ben_a_adams
content:
The data is literally saying the lengths of the data elements; seem irresponsible to ignore it and lay a presumed offset format on it? If it was C that's how you'd get buffer over/under runs. 

What if the deposit contract was written in viper or some other language that decided to encode packed? Is valid by the event log specification, would fail to be parsed

author: chay_z123
content: Will there be meeting notes posted regards the ACDE call this morning? Hoping there is an actual decision on how to provide a place to test in absence of Holesky

author: potuz
content: I would like to evaluate a Peer-DAS CL only fork as soon as possible, without the tx type changes, nothing else, and then immediately after, when ready, the EOF EL fork containing the new proof system and a change in the blob limit.  I believe it is a pretty bad idea to move from a possible CL-only fork for Peer DAS into making it a cross layer fork

author: potuz
content: There are other changes that come from adding cell proofs to the tx sender, not only the EL, but also builders and APIs need to change. I think we can increase blob throughput and have a clean fork now with what we have now. Without delaying the next fork that will include the blob increase and new tx type model

author: tersec
content: Apparently PeerDAS devnet-5 still uses an all-supernode setup. This is farcical

author: tersec
content: And in absolutely no way ready for mainnet

author: potuz
content: I agree, but still think Q3 is very reallistic

author: potuz
content: And if we make it an EL cross layer fork it becomes impossible

author: tersec
content: Maybe, but it means making realistic devnets first

author: potuz
content: sure, we should already be scheduling those

author: tersec
content: It also means addressing some of the other concerns about whether aspects of the proofs should be moved from CL to EL, which was partly discussed today but did not conclude. It's not even spec-complete

author: tersec
content: None of this (and there are other outstanding issues too) means that it can't potentially be ready by Q3, but it does mean that one can't just ship what exists after a little more testing to really be sure nothing has been missed

author: parithosh
content:
I just looked at our PeerDAS configs, we're running ~20% of validators as full nodes and NOT supernodes. Apologies for the confusion on ACD. 

So PeerDAS is currently running full nodes and not purely supernodes.

author: parithosh
content: Lighthouse, prysm and teku all have full nodes on the network

author: ralexstokes
content:
high supernode usage is good for testing basic code paths, stability in early devnets

of course this usage will go down as we get towards more realistic mainnet settings

author: arnetheduck
content: I'd be rather interested in _no_ supernodes, and how well the network degrades under adverserial conditions

author: parithosh
content: Yes I agree, we will do said testing - but we're taking it one step at a time. Also with validator custody it isn't possible for a no supernode network, unless there is no chain.

author: agnxsh
content: till just a minute ago, i thought it's an all supernode network, stability with full nodes is indeed good news

author: manunlp
content: That being said, all 5 prysm nodes have the `--subscribe-all-subnets` flag, making them all super nodes (Source: `docker inspect beacon`). I don't know for other clients.

author: agnxsh
content: additionally i think there's the cgc bug in the UI still there, which makes it difficult to find full nodes /supernodes from the UI itself, i'm not sure if has been resolved since devnet 5 launch

author: agnxsh
content: i can confirm all 4 nimbus pairs are supernodes ðŸ™‚

author: agnxsh
content: the peerdas supernode flag for Nimbus is `--debug-peerdas-supernode` and not `--subscribe-all-subnets` as you might not wanna subscribe to all attnets and syncnets even if you're a peerdas supernode ðŸ™‚

content: I'll make sure there's no unpushed config changes and report back.
